resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
lihalite commented on pull request #4648: ARROW-5063: [FlightRPC][Java] Don't create child allocator in FlightClient
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4648
 
 
   I was not able to reproduce the issue @BryanCutler described (at least with the simplistic unit test), and I can't find clear documentation either way on whether grpc-java internally shares channels (I think it does not, given that their suggestion is to create multiple channels in certain cases involving high throughput). Either way, we should at least test that clients seem independent.

BryanCutler commented on issue #4648: ARROW-5063: [FlightRPC][Java] Don't create child allocator in FlightClient
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4648#issuecomment-504568618
 
 
   Comment from ARROW-5063:
   >I think we're trying to solve this wrong way. The idea that a client has its own allocator that is closed as it closes out to make sure it doesn't leak any memory is a good thing.
   
   That is fine @jacques-n , the problem I had was when I called `FlightClient.close()` it also calls `channel.shutdown()` which seemed to break the grpc channel for other clients that were connected and caused a crash.  I guess I'll have to try out my code again to see if it is still an issue, but I basically followed `IntegrationTestClient` that loops over locations and make a client for each
   
   ```java
   for (FlightEndpoint endpoint : info.getEndpoints()) {   
         List<Location> locations = endpoint.getLocations();
         for (Location location : locations) {
           FlightClient readClient = FlightClient.builder(allocator, location).build();
           ...
           // readClient.close()
   ```
   Because of the error, I couldn't close the client and to check for leaks. That's why I thought it made more sense to not couple closing the allocator with closing the channel.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

users@infra.apache.org

   There should be no state sharing of independent channels from distinct
   clients. If so, it sounds like we have another bug and this is working
   around it instead of fixing it. To confirm, the client caused another
   channel closure or closing the client triggered the server to close all
   channels?

lihalite commented on issue #4648: ARROW-5063: [FlightRPC][Java] Don't create child allocator in FlightClient
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4648#issuecomment-505094688
 
 
   It sounds like Bryan found that closing one client channel would close other client channels. This adds a simple unit test for that scenario, but we should do more investigation (probably the unit test can be made more robust to ensure that multiple clients are active at once).
   
   AFAIK, some gRPC implementations do share channels internally; I believe C++ is one of them, but it also doesn't require you to close a channel explicitly.

   >To confirm, the client caused another channel closure or closing the client triggered the server to close all channels?
   
   From what I remember, multiple clients had the same location and seemed to share a channel. So closing one client, then trying to read from the next failed. I tried to debug what was going on with grpc internally but it was a bit confusing.. I'll try to reproduce the issue again and I'll open another JIRA if it still happens.

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
I ran into a problem when testing out Flight using the ExampleFlightServer with InMemoryStore producer. 

A client will iterate over endpoints and locations to get the streams, and the example creates a new client for each location. The only way to close the allocator in the FlightClient is to close the FlightClient, which also closes the read channel.  If the location is the same for each FlightStream (as is the case for the InMemoryStore), then it seems like grpc will reuse the channel, so closing one read client will shutdown the channel and the remaining FlightStreams cannot be read.

If an allocator was created by the owner of the FlightClient, then the client would not need to close it and this problem would be avoided. I believe other Flight classes do not create child allocators either, so this change would be consistent.
fields.summary: [Java] FlightClient should not create a child allocator

comments.body: I think we're trying to solve this wrong way. The idea that a client has its own allocator that is closed as it closes out to make sure it doesn't leak any memory is a good thing.
Since we couldn't reproduce the gRPC behavior, maybe I can rollback the change to the client and just keep the tests?
